Dice

Class Die

  • java.lang.Object
    • Dice.Die
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<Die>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    LoadedDie

    public class Die
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<Die>
    Die Class will run the dice rolling system

    • Constructor Detail

      • Die

        public Die()
        Die constructor will assign the values to sides and topVal. The value of sides determines the amount of sides on the die. While the value of topVal initiates the value. Since the random number generator counts from 1 - 6 it is important to initiate topVal to 1. This will allow the random number generator hold its value from 1-6. The constructor will call the second constructor and give it a value of 6. This is because, as the default constructor it has a default of 6 sides, and gives this to the secondary constructor.

      • Die

        public Die(int n)
        This is the second Die Constructor. It takes in n amount of sides
        Parameters:
        The - constructor brings in user data which represents the number of sides on the die

    • Method Detail

      • roll

        public int roll()
        Rolls the die to determine the number on the die. The value of sides indicates the range of the random number generator and topVal is the variable that will store the value of the die.
        Returns:
        the top value of the 6-sided die.

      • getTop

        public int getTop()
        Is looking at the top value of the 6-sided die to determine what the value rolled is.
        Returns:
        the top value of the 6-sided die.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object other)
        Tests to make sure that the number of sides and the top face are the same
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A True or False depending on if the value of sides and topVal are equal to the other.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Die otherDie)
        compareTo is used to compare objects to other objects. In this case, it will compare the die value.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Die>
        Returns:
        Will return the value of the compareTo. Which will be -1 if the sides are less than the other sides 0 if the sides are equal or 1 if the sides are greater than the other sides

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        HashCode will be called because of the equals class. Whenever an object is called more than once the hashCode must return the same integer provided. This will show that the values are truely equal. The value of the return should equal to the values of sides and topVal. If they are different then we know that they do not equal.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        Will return the values of sides and topVal.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Will return a string that indicates the status f the die.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        Will describe the status of the Die.
